Who doesn't love the glamour and excitement that come with being a model? On ANTM you get to see what it's REALLY like.

what was the quote by archbishop tutu at the end of the film about a person 's past ? this  quote encourages viewers to look at the present

Archbishop Tutu’s quote was: “Forgiveness unlocks the doors of a prison that locks out the past, leaving only the hopeful opening of a new future.” His encouraging words remind viewers that they can put the past behind them, move on, and work to create a brighter future. Instead of focusing on hurt, fear, or guilt that they may feel, Tutu advocates a stance of forgiveness in order to propel them toward creating a future filled with joy and hope.

A couple of cowpokes help a group of Mormons cross some rough country on their way to a new settlement. This low-key Western is unusual for Ford in that it lacks any big stars. Johnson gets top-billing but his is basically a supporting role, although he and Carey work well together. Dru is given little to do other than provide the love interest. The best performance is given by Ford favorite Bond, playing the leader of the Mormons. In fact, this role helped him land a starring role in the long-running TV Western "Wagon Train" before his untimely death at age 57.

Whoever cast this movie was a genius , every character in it is perfect for their part , and they  make the story incredibly realistic. The director used captivating dialogue between the characters, creating tension in moments of passion, joy, grief and sorrow. It didn’t seem like a movie but like real life playing before your eyes. All the twists, climax and climaxes captivates audience and compel to contemplate over the innate qualities of humans. It reveals great truth that makes the world spin- uncertainties and revelations from story encourages you to think about life.

In Mississippi, the former blues man Lazarus (Samuel L. Jackson) is in crisis, missing his wife that has just left him. He finds the town slut and nymphomaniac Rae (Chritina Ricci) dumped on the road nearby his little farm, drugged, beaten and almost dead. Lazarus brings her home, giving medicine and nursing and nourishing her like a father, keeping her chained to control her heat. When her boyfriend Ronnie (Justin Timberlake) is discharged from the army due to his anxiety issue, he misunderstands the relationship of Lazarus and Rae, and tries to kill him.

One of the genres that flourished during the decade of the 30s was the variation of crime fiction known as "the murder mystery", as the addition of sound to films helped to make a more faithful translation to film of what the audiences experienced in the original plays. And since horror films were very popular in those years, by enhancing the horror elements of the plots the murder mystery films experienced a popularity almost equal to what it enjoyed in the previous decade (in which the first movies of the genre were produced).

In one of the many Bugs Bunny-Daffy Duck cartoons, Elmer Fudd is out hunting, and Daffy tries to get him to shoot Bugs. Needless to say, Bugs has his own agenda. Moreover, "Rabbit Seasoning" makes interesting use of word order and pronouns (warning: it just might hilariously and royally mess up your speech).I think that probably my favorite aspect of this cartoon is the costumes worn by Bugs and Daffy. One of them seems like it would have been risqué for 1952 (especially in a cartoon), but they pull it off perfectly, as they always did.

MCBOING BOING is one of the cartoons that have stuck in my head over the years and finally decided to  go watch the movie after hearing so much about it. The movie did not disappoint! It had amazing and creative animations along with a comedic, lively storyline which was really interesting and entertaining. There were moments in the movie which kept me and the kids engaged throughout and even moments where it evoked different emotions. The overall quality was of the highest standard, with vibrant and beautiful colors that added life to each scene. Overall, the experience of watching MCBOING BOING was an absolute joy and certainly worthwhile.

This movie is a piece of the time in which it was made..... Realistic. Movies were not candy coated during the late 60s and early 70s. The producers did not try to create some happy ending that didn't exist. The lack of a happy ending would create agitation in the audience that, hopefully would spur them on to action. At least that's how it seemed at the time. In today's movie world this movie would probably not be done. There would, definitely, not be this ending, however realistic.

It has been recorded that John Ford made the "big, blockbuster" movies so that he could afford to make the "small" movies that he loved so well. Wagon Master, with a young Ben Johnson, is clearly one of his best, if not the best of his small movies. The location shooting, the wagons, the intricate work with horses, and the inclusion of the plains Indian are all trade marks of Ford. As in many of his other films, Eisenstein, the great Russian director's influence is seen in this film.

One of the better made for TV biopics , I just wish it had told us more . I have  heard this sentiment many times, mostly in reference to musical legends and those in sports who deserved to be told the entire story, not just what fit in the allowed airtime. If the writers of these biopics truly wish to pay respect to the subjects, they need to acknowledge the impact they've had not just on their immediate communities but throughout the world, or sometimes even our universe. All biopics should aim to at least scratch the surface of their story and allow viewers to draw their own conclusion.

The philosophical, meditative tone of this movie renders it one of a kind. I'd give it 10 stars for that alone. That being said, though, what hit me with particular force was what I take, possibly incorrectly, to be its Art Direction. Many of the interior shots feature a rich concoction of color blends seemingly based on very understated Munsell Color Model progressions and complementary juxtapositions. This makes the movie probably unrealistic to contemporary eyes, but, to me, very beautiful as an aesthetic work in itself.

Strange enough, shorts like this get a 10. Why? They are hilarious. This is hilarious. Notice a lot of the quirky humor. Dated and childish to toon naysayers, but they don't know what they're talking about. They got to know that cartoons aren't just for kids. The art in this is probabley the best non-Road Runner art of the 1950's Looney Tunes shorts. It's hard to come across something better than the art in "The Great Piggy Bank Robbery", although nothing ever will. This probabley runs a close 3rd or 2nd.

If you want to see a movie with nudity , sex , drugs , alcohol , brutal beating of a  teenage girl and twisted mayhem,

then the movie called "Butterflies Don't Lie" might be just the ticket for you. Despite all the carnage depicted, this film portrays the challenging moments of teenage life with engaging dialogue and touching emotions. After spending time with the four girls, the audience starts to feel their confusion, pride, embarrassment and self-loathing. In many ways, this film accurately and boldly captures the complicated drama that teenage girls must face.

Text Taken from 2001 Melbourne International Film Fest Guide.fuckland The title is a pun based on the film 's lead  character's surname; Tilluckman is the her first name. To Rosina, life is only taking place when something dramatic happens. Events and attitudes shift wildly; like everyone, she never likes to be bored and relishes any drama around her. While at college, Tilluckman tries to resist having boyfriends so that she can carry on focusing on her career and ambitions. This radical new outlook reflects her life now and highlights that something as simple as having no partner, could give her life new perspective.

The Killing Yard is a great film, although uneven at times. Morris Chestnut puts forth a phenomenal effort as a mentally wounded and judicially jilted prison inmate, and the presence of Alan Alda as his defense attorney is none other than genius. The emotion and raw reality portrayed in this film's "flashback" scenes have the ability of putting viewers directly into the midst of the events being pictured. I was not even born when the Attica riot took place, however, through extensive research, I find that "The Killing Yard" does the story all of it's fair justices.

I saw Riverdance - The New Show and loved it from the very first moment ! It is an energetic  fusion of dance, music and song that captivated me and brought the house down! From the Spanish Flamenco style to the modern Soft Shoe tapping of the feet and lively dances of the couple with complex rhythm-you feel immersed and mesmerized into the extraordinary story portrayed on stage. You instantly felt an ethereal connection to the spectacular landscapes of nature that's powerfully expressed with soul-stirring music, toiling drums and hypnotic chants. One cannot help but jump and sway to the thunderous rippling melodies coming from the stage!

Our America is multi-cultural , with so many sub-cultures . This movie simply tells a story of a snapshot in  time and puts the message out there that America

It is a reminder that in order for all of these sub-cultures to find harmony within the nation and achieve their maximum potential, everyone needs to be included and respected. Even more, we all need to live together peacefully and enjoy our differences to help bring forth this vision of togetherness. With everyone playing an important part and contributing positively, Our America has all the capacity for growth and progress for a bright future for all citizens.

An Intelligent and well obtained film worth to export ! In this exiting and really intelligent movie filmed entirely in  Cambodia, audiences all over the world could identify with it. From the emotional and profound message given to the public, this movie is able to empower viewers in a lasting manner. Although some film lovers find the storyline simple, many people come away feeling stimulated. People tend to watch the movie a few times so as to analyse the film at a deeper level, as well as gain an insight into what the film is truly conveying.

I viewed The Reader at Sugar, which is not an optimal venue for viewing anything, and the movie was by far the highlight of the evening. The technical elements were well meshed and it was obvious that Duncan Rogers had chosen his designers and crew well. But it was the story and it's delivery that truly made this short shine. Duncan Rogers' tight script was just what this evening of "shorts" needed. It neither meandered, as several offerings did, or preached to us. The Reader was simple story telling in it's best form, well cast by Rogers and beautifully acted.

Working at a movie theater as a projectionist , I have the opportunity to watch basically every movie that comes  out before everyone else. This job has been great for feeding my film fanatic side and allowing me to learn more about movies in the process. There is something about the crispness and clarity of film projected on the screen in a cinema theater that makes me appreciate the movie industry even more. The setup itself is quite challenging and demanding at times, but I take pride in performing to my highest caliber and leaving the theater customers and employees with a good movie watching experience.

I was expecting this movie to suck, but what I got was a pretty good slasher/gore film. Most of the death scenes are adequately brutal. The teens are decent, with Penny McNamee definitely the best of the bunch. Rachael Taylor looks like a young Christie Brinkley, but doesn't bring much to the movie other than that. Kane was good as the killer, and is totally believable as a fearsome juggernaut. I saw the "twist" coming from miles away, but I still enjoyed the movie.But what really stood out to me was the direction.

North and South is a miniseries from the `` golden age '' of television miniseries in the 1980s , which  stars Patrick Swayze and Elizabeth Montgomery. The series follows a loving but conflicted family divided between the Northerners and the Southerners. It chronicles their journeys through a violent civil war in 19th century America and tells the tale of how war brings families closer even when their opposing beliefs break them apart. Despite the split, the two families realize how alike they truly are, fighting for the same cause and dedicating themselves to standing strong even when standing against one another.

Well, okay, maybe not perfect, but it was pretty close. This movie jumped from crime drama to romantic goofball comedy and back again so quickly all the way throughout that it seemed like two different movies that played simultaneously and then joined up again at the end. But they did it smoothly, and some in the theater found the bloody parts (like the scalping scene) to be funny as well. I just about threw up, but I guess that's just me. Greg Kinear is perfect as a soap opera actor.

This is the best movie I have ever seen . It has it all tragedy and happiness love and hate  

The plot was gripping and captivating as we watch characters navigate life and find strength to carry on through extreme circumstances. The scenery is incredible and lush, capturing your eye as you go from scene to scene. What struck me the most were the lessons we were all taught - that in life there are ups and downs, you need to strive for and value what matters, find courage, and face hardships to find the greatest success.

The whole shorthand for supposedly being more aware in this weird time is that you are `` Blue '' . It means that when out and about, you're keeping to yourself, sticking to your bubble, washing your hands and following local mandates. You avoid any potentially high-contact situations and prioritize mental health with positive lifestyle choices. There’s a directness to “Be Blue” that can bring some level of comfort as well. Everyone else is trying to find some footing in the newly fractured normal of the past year—maybe remembering to Be Blue could bring more understanding and solidity to that effort.

Personally, I regard "The Egyptian" in an extremely favourable light.It was introduced to me by a well-known Australian movie commenter & critic named Bill who was renowned for his insight & broad vision of people & places & particularly of films. This movie fitted the Bill perfectly & I came to appreciate his commentary & enthusiasm for this movie that emerged all the more as I watched it, as I was literally drawn into it, minute by minute, beyond his introductory comments, on my initial viewing many years ago.To me, it was propelled, layer upon layer, within half an hour, into an intriguing & fascinating production!

For those who still prefer films focusing on human relationships, 51 Birch Street is a must see.By training the spotlight on his own family, Block covers terrain that is off-limits for most filmmakers. He explores a common but often unspoken family dynamic and does so without resorting to hyperbole or sensationalism. In fact, the film is deceptively low key at the outset. In addition to providing a probing look at one family - and, by extension, every family - Block has also chronicled a very specific period in recent history. I don't know if this was intentional, but unavoidable due to archival content.Highly recommended.

One of the genres that flourished during the decade of the 30s was the variation of crime fiction known as  hardboiled fiction. Hardboiled fiction gained great popularity in the 1930s due to its grittiness, heavy suspense and lack of glorifying the criminals. These books often followed a hard-boiled detective as he traveled from town to town with the protagonist hunting criminals, only for justice, but not for personal gain. Despite the problems of depression and war, literature's appetite for crime never weakened and its readers became comfortable with the form. Other crime fiction conventions such as humor and cozy puzzlers, also provided comfort and refuge during these trying times.

I first saw this on the big screen with my girlfriend. It was a fun romp with some cool music. Kristine was on the Playboy cover, and the centerfold, as I recall. She's really cute and perky and has lots of charm. The movie made me want to see more of her and so I kept a look out for her in other stuff. She's in Steven Spielberg's "I Wanna Hold Your Hand" and Barbara Streisand's "The Main Event" and Bill Murray's "Meatballs", plus lots of TV shows like Night Court and TV movies.

There are a few things in life that we ca n't experience more than once and the college experience is  one of them. It’s no wonder college is filled with excitement, from nights of fun and memory-making experiences. Despite the undeniable hype that college evokes, there are many educational opportunities to learn about leadership and responsibility. Each passing semester in college may come with growing stress and exhaustion. But by balancing that with planning and reflective journaling, it is possible to approach college in such a way as to reap lifelong rewards. Exploring new ideas and conquering tough academics should be viewed as satisfying growth.

One of the many backwoods horror 's that came out in the early eightes and fortunately this is one of  the better ones

Carnage serves as one of the forerunners of horror, mystery and suspense film genres that expanded and intensified in the following decades. This grisly yet comical rendition is heavily reliant on campfire horror folklore and exaggeration, leaving enough subtle layers for the audience to deepen their understanding as the movie progresses. Beyond being a token in the backwoods horror, the approach gives the picture an attempt at reinvigorating the old ideas of survival in hostile situations.

Craig Brewer is now officially a writer/director for whom I will see any film by, no matter how bad it may look. His debut, Hustle and Flow, was one of my favorites from that year, with its emotionally charged storyline and realistic, fallible characters. I wasn't quite sure what I would end up thinking after seeing this sophomore effort. The cast seemed great, the trailer used music effectively, however, it seemed like there was a good chance it would cross into absurdity, and fast. Fortunately, Black Snake Moan hits all its marks dead-on.

(My Synopsis) Rae (Christina Ricci) was a high school slut and nymphomaniac who connects with Ronnie (Justin Timberlake) to fulfill her needs. Ronnie must report to his National Guard unit and leaves Rae all alone. Rae is not alone for long, because she is the town tramp with a powerful need to hook-up with a man. After a party, Rae is taken home by a friend who ends up beating her half to death and throws her on the side of the road. The next day, Lazarus (Samuel L. Jackson) finds Rae and carries her home.

Flawless writing and brilliant acting make this unusually delightful and witty plot-twister one of the best American films I have  seen. It kept me at the edge of my seat, not just for its flawless presentation of humour, but for the audience's ability to create guesses in such a surprisingly entertaining and pleasing experience. The subtle detailing and chaotic pacing made it more gripping to watch. Each plot twist throughout the film seemed more creative than the previous one, taking us further and further into this untraceable world. The ending particularly remains one of the biggest mystery elements ever seen.

Strange enough , shorts like this get a 10 . Why ? They are hilarious . This is hilarious . The reaction these shorts gets is overwhelming as these can certainly stir a feeling of laughter with their content, characters and choice of jokes. It is no wonder that with every joke or quip that you land , you are seen with an unwavering fan following which keeps swelling each day . Clearly, these shorts keep their viewers entertained , and enticed which explains why their score is what it is . It comes as no surprise why everyone loves it!

There are many film now on DVD, but producers had forgotten some tittles of importance to many moviegoers. The Egyptian, along with El Cid and other favorites of the era of the wide screen, big budget epics had merit. Many people from my generation learn a lot about history of Egypt, medieval Spain and even the Incas, (The first time I heard from them was a very cheap adventure movie with Charlton Heston called The Treasure of the Incas), same happened to me with Egypt, or Rome seen many "bad" epics of the era.

With Nurse Betty ( 2000 ) , acclaimed indie film-maker Neil LaBute ( In the Company of Men , Your  Friends and Neighbors ) signed a contract for three features for Disney studios. LaBute kept producing amazing, intellectual works on personal relationships that made waves. His next major movie, Nurse Betty, was the highest grossing among all the three pictures Disney and Neil had in the deal. Despite being an independent comedy-drama movie with a star studded cast like Renée Zellweger and Morgan Freeman, the movie actually surpassed critics expectations at the box office and earned Academy Award nomination as well.

What can you possibly say? This is the uncut hardcore, musical Alice! It works too with a large energetic cast seemingly enjoying themselves to the hilt and whilst one could wish for a re-mastered version, I guess we are lucky to even have this video transfer. Pretty much a delight throughout. There are a couple of slightly off moments but this could have been embarrassing all through and it certainly is not. It also could have been and today would have been too camp. No, a very fine effort that is amusing, tuneful and just sexy enough.

My family and I normally do not watch local movies for the simple reason that they are poorly made , 

Instead, we prefer to spend our time playing a variety of different sports, some at our local park, or going for picnics on a summer day. Additionally, we use this time for leisurely activities like reading, watching a foreign film, or having quality conversations that make the time spent even more enjoyable. Occasionally we enjoy a home cooked meal with a classic movie we all grew up with or have come to like over the years.

I saw this movie when I was a lot younger but it captured me . I loved Orry and George  and it broke my heart when things did not work out the way I wanted. Whenever I watch it, I experience that same roller coaster ride of emotions all over again. Even today the musical scores hit me just as hard as the story itself. As someone much wiser said, when Orry and George stop hating and start talking, that's when things will get better for them. Those few moments between them still warm my heart every time I watch it.

Fuckland is an interesting film. I personally love the Dogma movement. I wish it had lasted longer. It seems to have already died. Many critics tried their damndest to shut it down. I don't know why. It's the most interesting movement to happen in the cinematic world since the French New Wave. Besides Fuckland, I've seen the first three in the series, Festen, Idioterne, and Mifune. They were all great, Festen being a masterpiece, in my opinion. Fuckland isn't up to those others. I was just fascinated with the filmmaking.

It's funny because I read all the reviews on this page after getting this movie and it's either a love it or hate it reaction. You'll probably either love it or hate it too. I think the best films are the ones that divide people because obviously they have some kind of impact. I'm in the five star camp because this film did a real number on me and made me want to go back and find out more about Afghanistan and Iraq. I have to admit that I was pretty tuned out when all that was taking place.

An stunning look at the ocean and the life in it.The Good:The camera work was absolutely phenomenal. Every shot is done beautifully.It was interesting seeing all the different animals that I could have never even imagined.David Attenborough has the perfect narrator's voice. No one could have done any better.The Bad:There were one or two different times where there was a reference to the Earth being 1 million years old ( I hold a different belief). Overall a TV series anyone can enjoy. I highly recommend buying it. 10/10 stars.

Police officer Dirk Hendricks ( Jamie Bartlett ) files an amnesty application Alex Mpondo ( Chiwetel Ejiofor ) .A member  of a security organization in the province of Cape Town. The organization initially expressed doubt that such an amnesty application could be filed without absolute proof of Alex's prior illegal activities, or evidence of active compliance. However, upon further investigation, Dirk learns of Alex's extreme acts of civil disobedience as well as his substantial risk for retribution for these activities. Ultimately, the organization agree that Alex was highly likely to suffer severely if a prosecution went forward, and granted his amnesty request.

That's a bad, raunchy, predictable, tacky, salacious soap opera? "The Best of Everything" is just such a guilty pleasure for me, something along the lines of "Valley of the Dolls". I mean, "Best" has everything. Somebody gets pregnant out of wedlock (when's the last time you heard THAT phrase? ), there are affairs everywhere, drinking, backstabbing, jealousy, and even a tragic but not altogether unexpected death.Caroline Bender (Hope Lange) and Mike Rice (the delicious Stephen Boyd) are the centerpieces of the goings-on.

"The bad dreams always come back again like unwanted friends," says Marion Fairlie, who with her half-sister, Laura, lives in a vast mid-Victorian country estate. "And last night I found myself in Limmeridge churchyard. Normally, people who are dead stay dead, just as normally it is the criminals who are locked up rather than the victims. But then, there was nothing normal about what happened to us..." And we're off on a first-class Gothic story of madness, deception and villainy, based on Wilkie Collins' great novel of Victorian mystery.

I could n't believe the eye candy from start to finish . Being a fan of movies directed by music  videos , I knew I was in for a real treat when I finally watched the film

The unique camera movements, intense scene transitions, along with unexpected surprises like smoke bombs, dynamic quick edits and immersive production were remarkable. The fast pacing that grabbed my attention didn't waver. I watched this captivating movie with one eye in pure excitement, not able to stop it. Moreover, the daring soundtrack seemed perfectly choreographed and often altered the energy throughout the entire experience.

i love this show ! it is amazing ... i can never miss an episode even if i 've already  seen it

I've even got friends hooked on it. They just have to watch it for themselves so that they know how fantastic the show is! Everyone looks forward to Thursday nights where we can get our fill of humor and a little heart-warming goodness at the same time. This show always puts me in the best mood, making it even better when a new episode comes out. I could watch it again and again and never get tired of it!

The trailer to this film focused so much on the chain (of course, because it's so sensational) that it missed most of the movie, which is about a developing, although rather simply drawn, relationship between Lazarus and Rae as they attempt to recover from their past pains with each other.Of course, with the premise of a nymphomaniac in chains, it's no surprise that there's plenty of implied sex involved. However, at it's core, Black Snake Moan is a basic tale of redemption and the healing power of helping another person along.

The best of everything . Just what is the best of everything ? It is different for everyone but for  me it's having a good job, doing what I love and feeling a sense of purpose. It is also surrounding myself with a great network of friends, having people around me who appreciate me and feel secure. Having time and resources to enjoy life, travelling and enjoying good moments. Having a roof above my head and having someone to love and be loved back. All this makes for me the best of everything.

If you are a fan of early Duke movies, this Lone Star oldie is a good one. What more could you ask for than Duke, Yak, and Gabby. Lots of good ridin' and shootin'!!! I found it amazing that Duke's singing voice was Bill Bradbury, who is none other than Bob Steele's twin brother. It has been reported that Bob Steele was a high school classmate and friend of Duke, so twin brother Bill may have been too. Anyway, if you like good, clean, early western movies don't miss this one.

I 'm not usually into dark/psychological thriller type things . However , SEIZING ME is really an amazing piece of  art . I found myself completely entranced by the masterfully written story, deeply unique characters and it’s sinister plotline that’s filled with many twists and turns. Each and every character and moment felt authentic and sincere, yet fully immersed with horror and edge. I came away from it deeply impressed and filled with excitement, looking forward to what else this author will bring us in future. I certainly believe they have cemented a secure place within this much cherished genre, easily rubbing shoulders with its most notorious greats.

I went straight to the big screen to view this kicker . This is the only flick that I know  about in town. So I ordered popcorn and took my seat, anxiously waiting for the start of the show. I watched the previews, laughing at the funny ones, eager for the main movie to begin. When the lights went out, it suddenly got really dark, the perfect atmosphere for the suspense-filled movie that I was about to witness. Finally, the big scene was here and I watched eagerly as my favorite character had their way with the problem at hand.

Two Hands is a highly enjoyable Aussie crime caper, which ultimately succeeds by the way the film easily combines tense dramatic moments, with very funny characters and situations, to give the film the right balance and feel. The comedy of the film occurs naturally, and the laughs haven't been set up too elaborately & haven't been too worked at. It really is very funny, thanks to the fact that each character in the movie is excellently cast, and that each actor/actress recognises and can relate to the Aussie humor. They portray it very well and very realistically.

Guess a few upscale film directors were sitting around sipping their absinthe , grappa , aramangac or jungle juice some  such local blended whiskeys that fill up there nightly dartouan type shenanigans

When their buzz settled down from the drinks and daily ideas started brewing among them . Nailing scripts , grips on actresses, inspirations. Dancing eyes awaiting reviews. All becoming serious again and conceding to hold heavy tails yet execute lion sizes shifts of professionalism while projecting spirits towards a critical sure following. These lofty conversations granted vibrations reverberating still round time through self titled renovations no one ever believed lived into revolution.

"The Honkers" is probably Slim Pickens best performance of all time. When we were shooting, everyone connected with the production figured that Slim was Academy Award material. Unfortunately, United Artists had a James Bond picture in release at the same time and did not devote much attention to "The Honkers". I personally feel this film was under-rated by most critics. Sam Peckinpaw's "Junior Bonner" was out at the same time and seemed to impress the critics more than our film. Also, Cliff Robertson had a rodeo film out a few months before our release and that might have hurt us, too.

This movie was awesome , if you want a movie with non-stop puns and laughter then this is right for  you 

I would recommend this movie to anybody that wants an enjoyable, fun time at the movies. Even my parents enjoyed the movie despite all the silly puns, which only further increased my appreciation of it. There were more twists and turns than any other film I've ever seen, and just when you think you can see the outcome of one thing another even more far fetched plot is introduced. It never gets boring, no matter what kind of movie you prefer, there's something for everyone to enjoy.

POSSIBLE SPOILERSNo one is likely to pick up a DVD of Red Dust without knowing that it is about South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission. Hilary Swank stars as a South African exile who returns to her home town as a lawyer representing Alex Mpondo (Chiwetel Ejiofer), a member of the South African parliament who was tortured by a prison guard, Pete Muller (Ian Roberts), who is seeking to escape prison by testifying before the Truth and Reconciliation Commission. They could certainly have found an actress who has or could imitate a South African accent; Ms. Swank makes no attempt whatsoever to cover her unmistakably American accent.

I've been waiting almost 25 years to see this hard to find horror thriller and I finally did since it's proper rebirth on DVD. Of course it didn't have the same impact on me as it would have if I had seen in it the 80s, but director Lieberman (his film "Squirm" is excellent) makes good use of the lovely Oregon location and takes the time to develop the characters, not just to have them dispatched in creative ways. A high note, Brad Fiedel's whistling music is really creepy and adds to the desolate proceedings making this great fun for genre fans.

I really think this movie deserves some Oscars ! I really do n't care what people can say badly about  this movie. I was moved, both to tears and to joy by this story. Every element of it, from the writing to the acting to the cinematography, was absolutely exceptional and stood out for its greatness. It was an incredible work of art and an important story to be told and discussed, which shows in how well-made the movie is. It proves just how powerful movies can be and has earned the right to receive the most prestigious recognition.

If you overlook the fact that the plot has been done many times , this is a hilarious and gleefully  exciting movie. The protagonists exude boundless energy and confidence and make the whole ride wild and silly. With its gross-out gags, extreme pratfalls and over-the-top action scenes, it’s always in high-speed overdrive with some brilliantly quirky dialogue which brings its core of invention to life. It creates moments of absolute madcap hilarity that really bring the action into their unique universe. The fantastical characters and out-of-the-box visual design perfectly represent its larger-than-life action sequences.

I have remembered this cartoon for over 50 years - what staying power it has ! It was funny and  enjoyable, I shared the memory with family and friends over the years. The original dialogue still sticks with me too, one that stands out: "Just take life as it comes one day at a time" -- an important message and life lesson still today. Since I'm the same age today as when the cartoon originally aired, I've certainly applied this advice time and time again in all types of situations. There's just something special and humorous about how the old cartoon distilled life's experiences.

'The Cell' is a journey into the mind of a serial killer and I mean this literally. The film is about the journey, about the world it shows during this journey, the destination does not really matter. In my opinion this journey through the mind gives such beautiful images other things do not really matter as long as they are not distracting. In fact, the story is pretty good.We start with Catherine Deane (Jennifer Lopez) in the mind of a catatonic boy. How this works exactly does not really matter, but it looks a lot like virtual reality.

I 'm a fan of independent film . Dialogue driven , character study pieces are where it 's at for  me. So it's safe to say I was hooked when I watched Sorry To Bother You. While it explores difficult social topics with finesse, I love how cleverly its meta-storyteller storytelling weds hyper-real visuals with cutting, dark comedy to advance the narrative in all its fable-like irony. While it did surprise me by unravelling into an entirely surreal world with exaggerated characterisations and one very original situation - and these aren’t something I usually like in independent cinema - I came to embrace it in all its eccentricity.

Having just watched this with my mother ( Who got it for Christmas ) i was thrilled to find something  so unique. It has been the talk of the dinner table ever since with my family fascinated by the premise of the show. I enjoyed the stunning visuals and mysterious soundtrack that aided in drawing viewers into the unpredictable and unfolding storyline. This made it all the more immersive, my family anxiously awaiting new episodes each week, desperate to learn how the main characters dilemma's would end up resolved. Even I, who once was reluctant to dive into this drama was soon a full fan.

I Love this movie ! I know some people might say that it was not a great movie , but 

I disagree! It had elements that made it exciting and unpredictable. There were never any dull moments; the plot always kept me on the edge of my seat and anticipating what would happen next. Moreover, the characters were well-crafted and played with finesse. The narrative had several important points that served to add depth and create compelling moments throughout the film. It is truly one of those special pieces of cinema that leaves an impact that does not easily go away.

Sure, it has its pretentious moments, it plays like art-house, live-action Fantasia, but it also has moments of deep beauty and humor. Omnibus films are always a problem, but I have always had a keen interest in them. I will now rate the segments individually.Nicolas Roeg - "Un ballo in maschera" - This segment may very well spoil the film for some people, because it is absolutely the worst of the whole bunch. It is difficult to follow, mostly because it tries to adhere to a clear plot (a hackneyed one, at that).

First of all, ignore the comment about how South Park should make fun of Republicans. Everyone is doing that now, why should South Park blindly follow what the rest of the media is doing? And what the Republicans are doing is more serious and less funny than Al Gore and his global warming hysteria.But all that aside, this episode is just plain funny. Al Gore's portrayal has to be one of the best caricatures of a politician I've ever seen, it was original, and it was based on peoples opinions of the man.

I ca n't help but notice the negative reviews this movie has gotten . To be honest , I saw  the movie and really enjoyed it. My friends also had very positive experiences watching the film as well. In my opinion , the movie had great dialogue, well-thought-out plot, and powerful acting. Perhaps the reviews the movie is receiving may be rooted in personal bias . Rather than get overly caught up in the noise, I suggest that one make their own opinion about this movie before basing it on what other have to say.

You will be able to tell within the first 30 seconds of this film whether you want to finish watching  it or not. For sure, it will get exciting after this introduction, as this movie is sure to put you on a roller coaster of feelings - if the movie gets off the track for a little bit, trust me it will make a graceful turn back in the story line, so the movie won't completely become uneventful. Just hang tight and the movie will develop at its own speed and make sure you savour every moment - good and bad - in the upcoming 2 hours.

It may have been inevitable that with the onslaught of "slasher" movies in the early 1980's, that a few good ones might slip through the cracks. This is a great "rare" film from Jeff Lieberman, who insured his cult status with his memorable 1970's films "Squirm" and "Blue Sunshine".Five young people head into the Oregon mountains (this movie was actually shot on location) to do some camping and check out the deed to some land that one of them has acquired. Before long, they will predictably be terrorized by a bulky killer with an incredibly creepy wheezing laugh.

I resisted watching 15 Park Avenue despite of recommendations, discarding the movie as a clichéd topic of extreme emotional dramas and over-the-top acting.Once in a while, movies like 15 Park Avenue come by and sweep you off your feet.The movie grasps your attention pretty early on and there is no moment to rest after that. Aparna Sen has done a wonderful job of gluing the audience to every line of the movie. The impeccable character development, "just right" amount of emotions and an enigmatic end to match it all...I have a renewed respect for Konkana Sen Sharma, who convincingly plays the schizophrenic Mithi.

Despite all it's trappings of style and cinematic invention, this is basically another serial killer thriller, following the same sort of plotline favoured by such old favourites as Silence of the Lambs ? team of cops follows the trail of (particularly nasty) murders, someone else gets taken and they somehow have to find out where they are before it's too late. Only in this case, the only person who knows, the killer himself (powerfully played by Vincent D'Onofrio) is in a coma and we need psychologist Jennifer Lopez' sci-fi mind-meld machine to get into his head and force him to tell all.

Our Family and friends enjoyed this movie very much . The theme was well handled by the Director with great  visuals . We all felt that this movie portrayed how valuable the ties between family and friends truly are, and how together, anything is possible. The message about the importance of togetherness resonated with everyone and had a lasting impact, leaving us with a new outlook on our relationships. Moreover, we left with a stronger appreciation for the special moments spent with each other. Everyone shared in their joy, with comments of satisfaction and enjoyment that we had watched such a thought-provoking yet lighthearted movie.

The most enjoyable pet movie since Scooby Doo and Garfield . The story revolves around a 23 year old inventor , Vincent King. Vincent invents a cutting-edge machine with the ability to transform his small, family owned pet store into an “evolved” pet palace, including an automated toilet, virtual reality experience, robotic dog wash and virtual fitness program. With the help of his Uncle Seth and his adorable animals, he opens his incredible invention to a crowded, overfilled pet palace that bring joy and amusement to both humans and their pets.

This is definitely one of the better documentaries I have seen looking at family relationships and marriage. I saw "capturing the friedmans" a short while ago and have to admit I thought this was better.The story is not an incredibly shocking one, but it is a great examination of trapped personalities and relational cold war. Block deftly guides the viewer through diaries, family footage and after-the-fact interviews; his interview style is sensitive and probing, and his insights are clear and measured.51 Birch Street is a great examination of personalities and relationships over 40-50 years of social change, the social fallout, and potential for redemption.

Even for sci-fi this movie is movie is a little out there. Alright, more than a little... My first thought after watching it was that i had just lost my mind.Don't watch this movie expecting another Darko. Darko fans are never going to like another Richard Kelly movie because of their freaky cult standards. Donnie Darko is a thing of the past, get over it.Richard Kelly loves making movies that make you feel stupid for not understanding the 'Deeper meaning' the first time you watch them. To be honest I had to watch The Box twice before I liked it.

1981's Just Before Dawn is one of the best tales of wilderness horror out there. It's one of the finest-made slashers of the 80's and it easily blows movies like The Final Terror, Don't Go in the Woods, or The Prey out of the water.A group of young adults come to check out the mountain property that one of the group has just bought. However they are not alone in the wild. A hulking in-bred murderer, who seems to be in two places at once, is lurking and apparently hates trespassers.

King of Queens is comic genius . Kevin James , whom plays IPS deliveryman Doug Heffernan is extremely funny ,  smart and never disappointing 

With Leah Remini as the spunky, life-loving and loving wife Carrie, it rounds off one of the most classic and complete comedies. Both provide belly-ache laughter without sacrificing any good comedy lessons that can be used in real-life. King of Queens is the picture of family bliss - sweetly mad at times but altogether inseparable, made to thrive and harmonize on air for its 8 seasons. Its versatile collection of miscellaneous guest stars like Victor Williams and Gary Valentine for sporadic reasons; made for unforgettable scintillating duologues.

Personally , I regard `` The Egyptian '' in an extremely favourable light.It was introduced to me by a well-known  critic in whose judgment I put great trust, and it was an extraordinary accomplishment in many ways. It transported me to a distant world I never imagined even existed and heightened my experience through intriguing and intriguingly simple details. For example, the style of cinematography used presented beautiful sceneries that both delighted the senses and provocatively mystified me with a world much different than the one I'm living. Its plot offered unexpected twists and unpredictable events and interactions that engaged me with intellectual suspense and suspense.

This movie is Wonderful ! I can watch it again and again . Robin hood is Perfectly cast , and  all the Action in it was superb! The music in the movie was beautiful. It complemented the grand atmosphere that is created when watching the movie. From the various effects to the exotic location to the lovely scenes, there's no doubt that Robin Hood is a visual masterpiece. I highly recommend that if you have not watched it already, then take the time to do so now. It will stay in your memory for years and bring you plenty of hours of wonderful entertainment.

I saw this movie with my girlfriends and we all loved it! It is so sweet and heartwarming, a real tear-jerker! I was still thinking about the story days after i'd seen the movie. It's such a beautiful story about the difficult things all families go through, it's something anybody can relate to. I really recommend this movie to anybody looking for a Saturday night rental. With your girlfriends, your family, your boyfriend, everyone will really enjoy it! :D It's a real story about a real family that would pull at anyones heartstrings.

The first thing I wanted to do after watching this film was watch it again (because I'd missed lots with all the laughing I did). I'm European and I've studied abroad and I've as good as lived with Spanish, french, Italian and German people. The film was full of stereotypes, which, more often than not, p*** people off, and reading some of the other reviews I see that it did p*** people off. But, this film gets the stereotypes so right I cannot fault it.

On watching this film, I was amazed at how media perception can mould a persons opinion of a celebrity. Karen Carpenter was a carefree, but very unconfident young lady, whose wonderful voice helped her and her brother Richard to soar the charts with wonderful songs. As with all celebrities of today, they were often criticised about their music as well as their looks, styles, etc. THis had a huge effect on Karen who raged a battle against her eating and drastically lost weight, which eventually caused her death. This heart felt film was not initially something which I would have thought of watching.

Wagon Master is a very unique film amongst John Ford's work. Mainly because it's the only one that is based on a story written by John Ford himself, the story that was elaborated by Frank Nugent and director's son  Patrick Ford and turned into a screenplay, and because of director's personal opinion regarding it, Wagon Master is the film John Ford called the one which `came closest to being what I had wanted to achieve', to say so is not to say a little, but as Ford confessed once to Lindsay Anderson, his favourite was nonetheless My Darling Clementine and not any other.

I 'm absolutely disgusted this movie is n't being sold . All who love this movie should email Disney and  encourage them to offer it in retail stores

I understand Disney might want to protect its original movie versions, but people want the BluRay of this original cult classic. Surely Disney can accommodate both old and new fans with an incredible offer? We, the fans, could flood Disney's email account and bombard them with messages, get into social media, create an online campaign, do anything to get their attention and change their minds!

Susie Q. is one of those rare , and sweet movies that give you a warm feeling . It 's  got it all. A heartfelt story with just the right amount of laughs. And as far as plot development goes, it never gets bogged down and carries on in a great pace throughout the movie. Plus, the originality of it leaves you smiling. The cast brings a brilliant level of detail to their characters. The kindhearted side characters that lead us along on Susie’s adventures create an added charm and make her family come to life.

When I saw the preview for this movie, I figured to myself, "here's another dumb TV movie that's written with the thought and complexity of a soap opera," but when I saw it I was surprised. Tiffany-Amber Thiessen stars (and proves that she can indeed act if given the chance) as a woman who falls in love with and marries a man (Now and Again's Eric Close) but begins to lose trust in him when a series of rapes begin to take place in her community.

"Americans Next Top Model" is the best reality show! I was entertained 99.9 percent of the time watching it.I kept my eyes open the entire time. (well, I did blink) It can be sad, funny, or addicting. (mostly addicting)"America's Next Top Model" kept me wanting more and that's pretty much the point. It is also on more that one channel. Sometimes it's on MTV other times it's not. I hope it gets more fans and grows to be a hit series!

when the gilmore girls started in Germany i did not want to watch them because for me it was just  too much about two grown ladies dealing with drama

After some coaxing by my friends, I decided to give it a try. To my surprise, I soon became a Gilmore Girls addict! It wasn't just the drama I was hooked on, it was also the positive, never-give-up attitude of the main characters Lorelai and Rory. I loved the light-hearted jokes they always made while they dealt with big problems like family turmoil and adulthood issues.

A good old-fashioned flight-and-revenge western, given a twist and a touch of gravitas by injecting a little black social history into its plot. Lead by Mario Van Peebles, who does OK, the gang of misfits on the run from Billy Zane's (seemingly unstoppable) army bigwig all acquit themselves well, their adventures plausible yet fun and exciting. There're some nice moody flashback scenes setting up the hero's character and backstory, a good shoot-out ending as our heroes defend the town from greedy white landgrabbers, and even Stephen Baldwin isn't bad in this enjoyable, quite powerful western.

After I 've seen this movie I find it hard to understand why so many people seem to hate this  genre

I was deeply affected by this movie, feeling so many strong emotions during it. While I couldn't explain why people are so opposed to this particular genre of movie, I understand why so many would stay away due to its particular content. Nevertheless, the experience of this movie is one I think that more should take up if they dare, as it offers something which no other form of art or entertainment can.

This show is my guilty pleasure all the way ! ! When I first tuned in to America 's Next  Top Model it made my teenage self take an enormous risk with fashion trends and social acceptance, but eventually came out more stylish than ever. By continuing to watch each cycle of models and create fanmade super-stylish couture-inspiration portfolios I got even more confident in my choices. At the same time I was getting a behind-the-scenes-view on a glamorous fashion industry and there is so much to learn! The show challenges our ideas of how people 'ought' to look while celebrating uniqueness in people.

`` Side Show '' is one of the weirdest Horror movies ever made from Full Moon Pictures . Very gory  and inventive. It features one of the strangest leading ladies ever to hit the silver screen. Candy is an artificially created super strong hulking woman whose intense powers are fueled by dark magick. Despite her enormous strength and odd appearance she's a tender heart and even more she desperately wishes to have friends. She soon meets Tony, a childhood acquaintance who recognizes her identity and friendship begins. The two team up to battle evil powers while attempting to return Candy's spirit to a body worthy of life.

Almost four years after the Iraq war started and we 're in a bigger hole than ever . That 's  because the Iraqi people are living in poverty, joblessness, and continued bloodshed, so 

In addition, Iraqis don't feel safe enough to leave their homes, school enrolment rates have plummeted, infrastructure has failed, and investment in critical services has diminished. Women have fewer opportunities and poorer prospects, whilst child labour, child trafficking, and refugee crises plague much of the country. Even international support has struggled to bring stability to Iraq, as power has not been sufficiently transferred back to the Iraqi people.

Cliché-avoidance is one of this film 's main achievements . When you hear a vague outline of the story   from impoverished aristocrats to wartime wanderings - it would be easy to assume it 's simply another so-called period piece . Yet its courage lies in subtly crafting an utterly human journey across decades, delivering rare moments of hope with sparing dialogue and touching tenderness - amidst turmoil and oppressive realities. Cinematography and effective use of period sound weave memories and intense atmosphere of profound joy and unrelenting sorrow, emotion brimming with intricate truths. On first viewing, it presents more questions than it answers – making repeated visits essential – despite no traditional exposition.

One of the most entertaining of all silent comedies is Pudovkin's short 'Chess Fever', a mad tale of how a rigorously intellectual board game could disrupt even the most carefully planned central economies. Such an unpromising comedic subject as chess found an earlier outlet in this delightful short. Two young men play the game earnestly against an artificial background, a painted set. This is in contrast to earlier Lumiere shorts such as 'L'Arrosseur Arrosse' or 'Repas du bebe', wherein the human activity was deliberately framed by a natural setting.

`` The Cell '' is an exotic masterpiece , a dizzying trip into not only the vast mind of a  madman but into an achingly distant universe of the supernatural

In this epic excursion we find ourself awe struck and wonder struck as we marvel at the chaotic scenes unfurling before our eyes. We can literally feel ourselves walking in a never-ending circular dream; lost within the illusive confines of this psychologically conscious vortex. Mesmerised, and mystified, The Cell takes us on an immeasurably outrageous odyssey through parallel dimension and world's above worlds. We confront alternate timelines and dark deities that demand entrance into a state of sublime anarchy.

when I first heard about this movie , I noticed it was one of the most controversial films of the  year. Since then I had been fascinated by the premise and the critical reaction to it. Even after so much discussion on the film, people's opinions continued to remain divided. It was one of those topics which raised debate even among intellectuals. Moreover, it was this unusual subject which was fresh, fearless, yet well researched. This film showcased why it takes great filmmakers to explore what lies in uncharted territory and make us see the same old truths in new light.

I really think this movie deserves some Oscars! I really don't care what people can say badly about this movie...because it's a really well played parts from Samuel L. Jackson, and mainly by Christina Ricci!! I'm a big fan of hers, right since I saw her in Addams Family...been trying to watch all things she makes, and this is absolutely one of the best parts she played!! I love her looks (even though people say she's not pretty...I think she is...and I love her eyes)!!

Where this movies differs from traditional Hollywood movie is that it shows a true depth of feelings . In Europe  or Latin America ,the entire picture with its genuine details adds to its meaning . Moreover, in this movie there is a heightened emphasis on understanding various emotions among individuals. It encourages us to stand firm and open in pursuit of better lives with solidarity instead of just escaping hardship and remaining inert. The appreciation of suffering by telling stories and life lessons drawn from their scenarios lends more interesting nuances and plays an imperative role in this film.

This was on odd film. I liked the adventure of it though it seems to be aimed at children. (SPOILER AHEAD) Ironically, the main character murders a federal official. Then he's a fugitive on the run. They later blow up his house and then he finally commits suicide. Seems like they should have just made it a film for a more mature audience or made it more family friendly.This was on odd film. I liked the adventure of it though it seems to be aimed at children. (SPOILER AHEAD) Ironically, the main character murders a federal official.

Craig Brewer grew up in Tennessee, it is evident in his movie. Forget the Black guy on White Girl action. It happens, but it isn't Samuel L. Jackson on Christina Ricci. More importantly this movie is about the values and culture of the people in this Tennessee town. How they deal with divorce, abandonment, sexual abuse and psychological disorders. While shrinks make millions in the cities of the North, Midwest and West Coast, the town minister, who also grapples with his own problems, becomes the counselor and mediator.

Every time I hear Karen Carpenter 's voice , there is that old familiar feeling of 70 's blues . It feels like she's in the room with me - tapping her foot in time, bobbing her head and cradling the mic with those gorgeous pipes. For me it conjures up a warmth and security that has always felt comforting. She understood the emotions of what life was about. I can't quite put it into words - but when I hear her singing I feel a distinct pleasure. Nothing can match it. Karen Carpenter has forever embedded herself in the rhythm of my heart.

This is a great concert which featured the best songs of the band 's 30 year career . Lee ,  the lead singer and bandleader, shared personal stories that accompanied each song as they told the stories of their music. The show also included some unexpected fan favourites, as well as several surprises. At the end of the concert, the band even played one of their biggest hits - much to the delight of the audience. Many fans went home with not only their copy of the newest album, but also a sense of excitement over what's to come in the next 30 years of the band's legacy.

I 'm certain that people from USA do n't know anything about the rest of the world , but I  disagree

The truth is that many people from the USA may not have traveled to a lot of the rest of the world, but they do often have an idea and awareness of its diversity. There are always ways of accessing knowledge like the internet, books, tv and more to gain an understanding and have meaningful conversations about different parts of the world. In many parts of the US, it has become quite popular to attend various international events as well, celebrating the unique flavors of different cultures and bringing greater understanding.

There is a clever little scene in The Karen Carpenter Story, where both Carpenters are in a recording studio, and Richard makes an impromptu decision to have Karen sing for the owner of the studio.Richard picks the wrong key for Karen to sing in, so Karen is singing above her natural range. You can see a look of bemusement on the owner's face; he figures she really can't sing. Richard quickly realizes his mistake and tries again in a different key. The next thing you hear is Karen's amazing, beautiful voice, and the owner does a priceless double take.

The film begins with a cranky old Broadway producer ( exceptionally well-played by veteran character actor Richard Carle ) being  urged by two ambitious journalists

As Richard Carle refuses to yield his answers, the two reporters realize that he is far too secretive and disgruntled to explain his story and present their evidence to the public. To the viewers surprise, they manage to grab Richard by his socks and persuade him to come along with them to uncover some secrets. In the subsequent adventure, Carle experiences different and diverse twists to explore that profoundly challenges his inhibitions and strengths.

Not knowing a great deal about the Truth and Reconciliation commission, I can only look at this as a piece of entertainment. I started watching it too late in the evening (recorded from BBC2 earlier this year) but once I'd started I had to watch to the end.The down-side is that it's effectively a courtroom drama - never my favourite genre - but it's stunningly photographed (largely in super-saturated ochres) and well acted. Like a good novel, I couldn't put it down. All the way through, I wished I was watching it in a cinema to do the music and photography justice.

The make -or-break of a love story for me is whether or not I like the characters and also if  there is good chemistry between the two leads. I personally have a hard time accepting a love story when it feels fake. No matter how many wild plot turns a romance novel takes, if it feels rushed, or unbelievable, it becomes hard to get invested. Seeing a relationship gradually build chemistry and form, usually out of sheer curiosity or even repulsion towards each other, has become essential in drawing me in and keep me hooked to the story.

I'm not the biggest fan of westerns. My two personal favorites though are Unforgiven, and Tombstone. This movie though, I loved! It was great! The plot was well done, and it was a fun movie. Everybody who had a part in this movie did excellent! I even think it beat out both movies in someway. Well, not really Unforgiven because that was a superb movie that these two can't compare with in the long run. I do think it beat out Tombstone though. Both had there strong points.

Tex Avery's tenure as director of cartoons for MGM was in the 1940s and 50s was one of the brightest moments in cartoon history. His cartoons were exceptionally inventive and surreal with MANY weird touches that were later celebrated in the movie THE MASK. Eyes popping out when a guy sees a girl, impossible stunts and non-stop action were the trademarks of these films.This is one of several Droopy cartoons that Avery was responsible for and it's among his best. Droopy is a Mountie and he is determined to get his man,...though in this case it's a wolf who has escaped from prison.

If this is not my favorite movie of all time, it definitely is in the top five. I love this. Everything about this is perfect--the clothes, the set, the lines--yes, they're not how normal people talk, but... Right down to the small scenes, especially at the beginning of the office girls changing their shoes, picking a wedgie, watering the office ivy plant, putting lunch in the fridge... Identical to what us office girls do today in the year 2005. I think all the minor characters are wonderful.

i love this movie. is it on air anymore? what can i do to get it on air again because i miss this movie when does this movie air again? i love this movie so much. does anyone know how long it has been since it was last on Disney?it has been a very very long time and i am so sick of waiting!i want to see Susie Q again. i swear, they take all the good movies off air and play new stupid gay ones that are fake and retarded.

I just saw this wonderfully filmed movie that captures the essence ofhigh-brow NYC , or any big city of mid-century  

It's an aesthetically captivating exploration of existential themes involving city living and ambition; watching the character try and overcome impossible challenges was incredibly inspiring. It takes us through the plot filled with atmosphere and conflict, sprinkled with romance, light comedy, suspense and dread. This film served as an ode to every downtrodden ambitious person, rising up despite difficulties in our times; while concurrently validating each person's wish to create a better life in the big city.

Cant believe it .... after all these years finally tracked this down .. it was meant to be named 'The  Blue Woman'. It was something she had lost years ago. Looking for clues online for so long with no luck, she had just about given up when she found something - the story of a woman called 'The Blue Woman'. Every clue she'd gathered since her search began had all suddenly come together. With trembling hands she sent a message in hopes of it being her and crossed her fingers. Low and behold, there was an instant reply.

America's next top model is a good show, it helps people with their careers, but lately i have become bored with it.cycle 1: yeah I'm happy Adrienne won, i wanted her to win from the beginning.cycle 2: its too bad, i think Mercedes deserved it.cycle 3: i did not like Eva, but i did not like most of the girls in this cycle.cycle 4: Kahlen should have won. i don't know what they saw in Naima, but i definitely know what they saw in Kahlen.cycle 5: like cycle 3, this was not a great cycle either.

Enjoyable film that gives you romance, women-on-the-verge psychodrama, work place sexual harassment, adultery, and fashion. It's all there. Typical characters found in corporate America. Joan Crawford is the usual long time employee bitch executive who feels the need to be such because she's with the big boys. Hope Lange is the entry level ambitious employee whose determined to get to the top by using her mind and not her body. Their personal lives is the subplot. Wardrobe for the film is great but someone forgot to tell Stephen Boyd's hairstylist that "a little dab will do ya!"

On watching this film , I was amazed at how media perception can mould a persons opinion of a celebrity 

Media perception can be both good and bad. As I watched this film I realised how the negative aspects can outweigh the positives, it seemed every single story was slanted toward portraying this person as having done something wrong or portraying them in a bad light. This situation had reached the stage where, although none of the allegations made were proven to be true, this persons image in the media was still being tarnished and effecting their career.

As a dedicated lover of all things Egyptian this is a classic piece from the 50's, along with my other favourite, Land of the Pharaohs". The sets and colours are just wonderful and everything seems so "neat" in the production quality. I thought Victor Mature was well cast and Peter Ustinov a real gem! The whole look of the movie (along with others made in this era) has an appeal that you just don't get with modern movies with all their digitized effects (I have yet to see the 1999 movie "The Mummy but am sure I will love it!

Robert Altman, Nicolas Roeg, John-Luc Goddard--you were expecting a fun film the entire family could enjoy? These and other directors were obviously chosen because they have not followed the mainstream, but created it. For those that complain that they did not adhere to the original story of the opera--How often does the music in a film directly relate to what is going on in the film? It is the mood that counts. This is what I believe the directors of these movies were doing: creating a contemporary mood for old operas. For the most part they succeed wonderfully.

After I've seen this movie I find it hard to understand why so many people seem to hate this movie. I'm not saying it belongs in the top 250 of all times, but in it's genre it is a great movie. I know, not many people find it amusing to see how a legendary story like 'Robin Hood' is turned into a comedy. Many people still seem to believe that some things shouldn't be laughed with ... they are wrong. Mel Brooks has done an excellent job with Robin Hood: Men in Tights.

I saw the movie in 1972 , and like other people who have commented on it here ... I went  back to see it many more times. I developed a fondness for the music, the atmosphere and the many remarkable actors, particularly Agnès Varda and Mona Knapp. The cast shared in many interesting and diverse interpretations that resulted in multiple commentaries on social norms and environmental chaos. I highly recommend watching this French classic as I'm sure many will appreciate the candid conversations and expressioins of daily life, deeply enveloped in symbolistic metapyhs.

1981 's Just Before Dawn is one of the best tales of wilderness horror out there . It 's one  of those gems that is found on very rare occasions and should definitely not be passed up by moviegoers looking for a suspenseful journey. The movie centers on four friends in search of a local legend during their outdoor getaway. Once they enter the forests, they are thrown in the middle of a nightmarish experience in the form of mountain folk seemingly content to terrorize unsuspecting campers. Through some unusual shots, the movie offers a truly gripping portrait of those condemned by these beings who decide to live among them.

I viewed The Reader at Sugar , which is not an optimal venue for viewing anything , and the movie  didn't seem to do justice 

However, when the movie ended and I got some time to process the whole experience, I started appreciating it. I liked the storyline and appreciated its symbolism. I found it an impactful film and thoroughly enjoyed it in spite of the fact that I hadn't liked the theatre experience. Despite having my qualms with Sugar ,I also came away with a completely different outlook and viewed the venue differently too.

honestly.. this show warms my heart, i watch it EVERYDAY on fox family and now that the new season has started i'm even more hooked than before.. the characters are so well-developed and their relationships are so real.. i would recommend this show for any woman or mother and daughter.. the Lorelei's are super fast talking witty girls that will, truly inspire you and the show is hysterical at times and never too too serious, but serious enough for it to be completely addicting.. it's an hour long which is a major PLUS because you can't ever get enough Gilmore!

Loved the shots of airports -- Dallas, Phoenix, Fresno, etc., just single buildings with the name in block letters on the roof. And the tri-motors, and the well-dressed passengers. Fast-forward 75 years....But what really got to me was the hammer and sickle emblem and what appeared to be a Chinese ideogram adjacent the logo, aft of the pilot's seat on the starboard side of the fuselage. Remember when the mutual acquaintance Neil and Jill encounter says that Jim'd become a general in a Chinese rebel army?

This is what porn used to be, this is a true classic. I mean, it is an x-rated musical based on an actual book! There is a real plot to it and how many x-rated movies can boast that these days? This belongs in an exclusive short-list of true pornographic movie classics, including Debby Does Dallas, Deep Throat, and Behind the Green Door. I think the problem with "pornographic movies" these days is that it's all about the "pornographic" and not about the "movie".

Having read the other comment about this superb piece of TV drama I felt compelled to balance things a little  and provide another viewpoint. I thoroughly enjoyed this piece of TV drama from beginning to end and would highly recommend it. I particularly enjoyed the character interactions between the protagonist and the rest of the cast and it felt very organic throughout the show. I believe the key strength of the show was its realism which grounded the writing and story and added to the power of the piece overall. There were some weak moments along the way but nothing which marred my overall opinion on the show.

I got this movie with my BBC `` Jane Austen Collection '' ( 5 DVDs of old BBC adaptations ) 

At first I was a bit skeptical since there was no bonus material whatsoever on the boxset. But to my pleasant surprise, all the BBC Jane Austen adaptions on the five discs turned out to be absolutely excellent. All five featured flawless acting and top-notch sets and costumes. The film quality on all five discs was also superb; making for a great nostalgic journey and insight into what some of our classic novel looked and felt like in different adaptions and adaptations from the 1990's.

I caught this flick on the trail end of a tape I had used to capture a movie I truly wanted to wanted to see again. When I saw Raquel Welch's name in the opening credits, I decided to watch it. It was actually mildly entertaining, and took me back "in the wayback machine" to the farcical movies that Hollywood churned out during the sixties, much in the same genre as the current Austin Powers stuff. Oh the acting was not superb, nor was the plot, but it was worth watching.

When I was engaged, my fiance and I would frequent the adult bookstores. He would look for his favorite mags, and on occasion a video that caught the eye. As much as I enjoyed the one-on-one with him that the media caused, there was never a video that I really enjoyed. I had seen only one other movie way back when there was a satellite channel called XXX (it dealt with a private eye unraveling a case) that actually had a proper plot and was enjoyable. All the others were grunting and puffing and blowing and whatnot.

Based on Mika Waltari 's Book , This Second CinemaScope movie ever made is full of rich color , beautiful  Finnish music , high adventure , dangerous encounters with smugglers

Set against the dramatic landscape of Finland in winter and laced with the mesmerising beauty of winter landscapes and elven magic, The Adventures of Andre Anger delivers a touching coming of age story, wrapped in a rollicking action adventure. Little Andre and his mysterious yet stubborn companion spend the icy nights telling stories around campfires and journeying through thick forests and wild moors, navigating hazardous smugglers as they venture closer to the remarkable secrets held at an abandoned farmhouse.

Don't you ever miss the good old days when Disney actually made great movies that really moved you? Growing up with Disney I always found myself being captivated by the characters. Every single one seemed truly talented and knew how to act their way through a movie. I remember Friday nights and running to turn on the TV just to watch their newest movies. Susie Q was one of my all time favorites. I never forgot this movie. Even till this day when one mentions the song "Susie Q" I always remember the movie.

Craig Brewer grew up in Tennessee , it is evident in his movie . Forget the Black guy on White  boy shootouts Memphis and ...

Craig Brewer pulls from real locations around Tennessee when constructing his scenes. As he reflects his hometown, we get to meet his lead characters living the hardships and thrills that can often make Memphis music. We have Andy looking for musical career break as Tommy gives back to his past after new release. Aside from creating his alluring movie style, he finds authenticity in creating realistic characters trying to remain determined in all difficulties coming their way.

I saw Chomps during the - approximately - 2 days of its theatrical release. It is a delightfully cute and funny movie in the spirit of 'Benji' though much improved and focused more on the actors than the dogs. The simple portrayal of life difficulties in a humorous way, followed by the bullies and villains getting their just deserts, is both sympathetic and heartwarming. It is also thought provoking. With deft subtleness this movie affects ones awareness of cruelty, personal behavior, and bullying. Movies have different genera's and different purposes.

Watching this film caused quite an emotional reaction. This is what today's documentaries are all about. It's refreshing to watch something so personal, honest and real. Mr. Block's thoughts, opinions and disclosure are rarely seen these days and are incredibly well displayed here. It's a fine line to walk between personal truth and exploitation. This film treads very carefully and quite successfully.One would think that learning about how a seemingly normal couple falls short of society's expectations would give birth to pessimism...but it doesn't. Quite the opposite: it made me feel good.

Wagon Master ( 1950 ) Dir : John Ford Production : Argosy Pictures / RKO Radio Pictures John Ford brings  together Ben Johnson, Harry Carey Jr. The classic western, 'Wagon Master', released in 1950, was the very first western directed by legendary filmmaker John Ford. Produced by the classic filmmaking companies Argosy Pictures and RKO Radio Pictures, and starring the iconic stars Ben Johnson and Harry Carey Jr., the plot of the movie follows a small town dreaming of striking out to begin their own settlement away from an advancing railroad.

People need to give this show a chance. The people who write bad reviews (there are very few of them) are clearly people who haven't seen many episodes. One needs to really sit down and pay attention to this show to appreciate it. All of the characters are realistic because they have so many flaws. They make mistakes, but they are REALISTIC mistakes, which is an uncommon thing to see on television today. Also, for the most part the acting is superb. Lauren Graham has been snubbed of an Emmy for six years now.

There are a few things in life that we can't experience more than once and the college experience is one of them. Especially if we're living in a foreign country and in a apartment with 6 wackos from 6 different countries. Xavier the main character leaves his tidy life in Paris, his ex-hippy mother and his beautiful girlfriend and goes to Barcelona to study spanish in order to get a job at the embassy. He falls in love with the wife of a french doctor and he makes friends that make him look at things differently.

Jimmy ( Heath Ledger ) is given a simple job by Pando ( Bryan Brown ) a underworld kingpin to  investigate the mysterious owner of the club, Harold Valentino ( Malcolm McDowell). Jimmy embarks on an underworld investigation full of secrets and danger to reveal the secrets of Harold Valentino and Pando. Despite numerous threats and consequences, Jimmy doggedly carries out his assignment.
